ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about various different fields within neuroscience and their accompanying differing methodologies
Presentation skills, practice reading scientific papers, lit review/proposal writing, and discussion of various developments in neuroscience in different disciplines via research papers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: At first, giving a presentation every other week sounded like a lot but it got easier with practice and I honestly think it is one of the most useful practical skills that we could have, especially if we intend to continue in academia or in a lab where presentations are routine. The small setting enabled all of us to present very often so if the course is offered again (I hope it is, at least as a senior seminar option). Discussions became easier throughout the course and I think we all got a lot of practice paper reading (4 papers per week) which will also be extremely useful in the future for many of us. I did like the variety of papers that we read, but I think the major should develop more of these senior seminars, perhaps with more specialization like MCDB has with for example MCDB 387, MCDB 415, MCDB 450 - all of which get great reviews from students. The greatest weakness was probably the ambiguity in the feedback/grading because everyone did a lot of presentations and we weren't really advised on how we could improve after each one. On occasion if you were assigned to present on the first Monday of the next unit, the papers weren't assigned until like Saturday night which made it difficult to really digest/understand the material you would be presenting before the presentation. Finally, I think I would have appreciated a little more guidance on the final proposal guidelines because the sections were different in the syllabus and in the assignment on Canvas and having never written a proposal before I ended up just Googling some common outlines. Some examples from past years (or even from real grants) would have gone a long way.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: class was able to be run pretty well remotely!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this was a great course for learning practical skills in a less intense environment and for getting to actually engage with the DUS'es on a routine basis to learn about the state of research from experts in the field. It was a great way to introduce students to what they would likely be encountering if they continued in the field so I definitely recommend taking it if it is ever offered again.
